articles.headline: Fitbit Strives to Escape the Shadow of Apple
articles.snippet: Fitbit, a leader in wearable technology, is growing both in staff and sales, but it struggles with public comparisons to its larger rival Apple.
articles.abstract: Fitbit, a leader in wearable technology, is growing both in staff and sales, but it struggles with public comparisons to its larger rival Apple.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Earlier this year, Fitbit invited guests to a Las Vegas hotel to witness something that it promised would “ignite the world of health and fitness.”

articles.headline: Opioid Prescribing Gets Another Look as F.D.A. Revisits Mandatory Doctor Training
articles.snippet: Several groups are working to reduce the inappropriate use of painkillers.
articles.abstract: Several groups are working to reduce the inappropriate use of painkillers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A pain management specialist, Dr. Nathaniel Katz, was stunned in 2012 when the Food and Drug Administration rejected a recommendation from an expert panel that had urged mandatory training for doctors who prescribed powerful painkillers like OxyContin.

articles.headline: Warren Buffett Holds Forth on Sharing the Wealth
articles.snippet: At “Woodstock for Capitalists,” Mr. Buffett cautioned against killing “the golden goose,” saying instead that we “need to make more eggs.”
articles.abstract: At “Woodstock for Capitalists,” Mr. Buffett cautioned against killing “the golden goose,” saying instead that we “need to make more eggs.”
articles.lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Priyanka Bodalia, a 24-year-old from Cincinnati who works in accounting, was roaming the convention center here where Berkshire Hathaway’s annual meeting was taking place Saturday afternoon. She couldn’t have been more excited to hear from Warren E. Buffett, the company’s chief executive, and his partner, Charlie Munger, as well as to see the parade of boldface names that made the pilgrimage.

articles.headline: On Streets of Syria’s Capital, Even the Sweet Is Sour
articles.snippet: Declan Walsh provides an on-the-ground report from Syria’s capital, where residents, spared the worst of the violence, respond to a seemingly interminable war with skepticism and dark humor.
articles.abstract: Declan Walsh provides an on-the-ground report from Syria’s capital, where residents, spared the worst of the violence, respond to a seemingly interminable war with skepticism and dark humor.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — Adnan Gimaah was perhaps the sourest purveyor of sweets in the old souk of Damascus.

articles.headline: South Dakota Wrongly Puts Thousands in Nursing Homes, Government Says
articles.snippet: The Justice Department said Monday that with few alternatives available, thousands of people were held unnecessarily in highly restrictive group homes.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department said Monday that with few alternatives available, thousands of people were held unnecessarily in highly restrictive group homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When patients in South Dakota seek help for serious but manageable disabilities such as severe diabetes, blindness or mental illness, the answer is often the same: With few alternatives available, they end up in nursing homes or long-term care facilities, whether they need such care or not.

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Foes Fear Indiana Primary Could Be Decisive Blow
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump appears poised for a victory there that would put him on track to seal the Republican nomination as polls give him a clear advantage.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump appears poised for a victory there that would put him on track to seal the Republican nomination as polls give him a clear advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: The coalition of Republicans opposed to Donald J. Trump’s candidacy braced Monday for a debilitating setback as he appeared poised for a victory in Indiana that would put him on track to seal the Republican nomination by the time primary voting ends next month.

articles.headline: Resettling the First American ‘Climate Refugees’
articles.snippet: A $48 million grant for Isle de Jean Charles, La., is the first allocation of federal tax dollars to move an entire community struggling with the effects of climate change.
articles.abstract: A $48 million grant for Isle de Jean Charles, La., is the first allocation of federal tax dollars to move an entire community struggling with the effects of climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLE DE JEAN CHARLES, La. — Each morning at 3:30, when Joann Bourg leaves the mildewed and rusted house that her parents built on her grandfather’s property, she worries that the bridge connecting this spit of waterlogged land to Louisiana’s terra firma will again be flooded and she will miss another day’s work.
articles.byline: By Coral Davenport and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: Workers Are Getting a Bit More of the Economic Pie (and Shareholders Less)
articles.snippet: Employees are regaining some bargaining power lost in the recession, but not the power lost over the last three decades.
articles.abstract: Employees are regaining some bargaining power lost in the recession, but not the power lost over the last three decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: American workers are reaping fewer of the gains of a growing economy in the form of pay and benefits. Shareholders are reaping more in the form of corporate profits. That shift has been one of the most important economic stories of the last several decades, and it is the key to understanding stagnant wages for middle-class workers and a soaring stock market in the last quarter-century.

articles.headline: Women in Tech Band Together to Track Diversity, After Hours
articles.snippet: Eight women formed Project Include, a nonprofit effort to collect and share data, hoping to diversify the rank-and-file in Silicon Valley’s tech companies.
articles.abstract: Eight women formed Project Include, a nonprofit effort to collect and share data, hoping to diversify the rank-and-file in Silicon Valley’s tech companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Ellen Pao spent the last few years spotlighting the technology industry’s lack of diversity, in court and beyond. Erica Baker caused a stir at Google when she started a spreadsheet last year for employees to share their salaries, highlighting the pay disparities between those of different genders doing the same job. Laura I. Gómez founded a start-up focused on improving diversity in the hiring process.
